Stage 5: Demo Day and Post-Accelerator Opportunities
The most significant impact will come in the weeks, months, and years after finishing the program.
Tips for an Online Demo Day
Tools used: 
Main presentation event: Zoom (can be streamed from Zoom onto Facebook Live if preferred) 
Networking with team tables: Remo, Airmeet
All event slides and slide decks are compiled into one presentation: Google Slides 
Tips: 
Have each team have their timer on their end, so they track their own time and stop on time. Make sure to inform the teams before the session on their pitch duration so that they practice accordingly. The goal is to prevent the moderator from cutting them off publicly, but it is also essential to be strict about keeping to the time limit (possibly with a 10-15 second buffer, max). 
The presentation order, tables, and list order on any forms should all be numbered and aligned precisely the same way. 
Have the team name, presenter’s name, team members' names, and “presentation number” of the last team on the slide to stay visible to the audience while scoring. Perhaps it could be the team’s title slide with that additional information added. 
Have different staff/team members moderating, time-keeping, making slides/music, etc. Split up roles so nobody is multitasking too much. 
If technical limitations make it challenging to give the presenters the ability to control the shared screen, have all the teams presenting snap their fingers, so they don’t have to keep saying “next” out loud. 
The person presenting should turn their video off if the sound is glitchy. Most importantly, their voice and the slides, though seeing them speaking would also be lovely if possible. 
Everyone turns on their microphones at the end to clap for all the teams. :-) Maybe we even do that during the opening “tadaa” to hear everyone’s voice. It is nice to do at the closing of the event as well. 
Encourage teams to present standing up, not sitting down, so they need to set up their laptop (and headphones) in a way that would allow that and not have that be at an awkward angle. 
Encourage all teams to use headphones for better sound quality. 
Encourage all teams to do some warm-up exercises before the presentation. For example, super-hero pose, jumping jacks, stretching, running in place, dance, “coffee breathing,” etc. 
Make things easy for people to switch between Zoom and Remo; create onboarding videos to share with all attendees ahead of time, and encourage them to join Remo / and sign me. 
Encourage teams a week in advance to start inviting their family/friends/future investors.
All teams put their username/screen name as “Team Name - Full Name.” 
Use zoom dual monitors > Show participants screen 
Encourage teams to practice, practice, practice! 
Hype up the teams! :-) 
Slide Preparation for an Online Demo Day 
Having a smooth flow between presentations is vital. Having all presentations in one Google Slides presentation can improve the flow substantially. 
If possible, test ahead of time. You can give participants the ability to control the person sharing the screen. It will allow each speaker to control the slides themselves. However, it often doesn’t work as smoothly in practice because of technical issues, internet delays, or little comfort with the online tools. 
Advanced Google Docs users can have the teams use separate presentations linked to one master presentation. For example, when copy-pasting from a team presentation into the main presentation, choose “linked slides.” This way, when the teams update their presentations (just those slides), the master presentation is automatically linked.
Tip: Once a presentation is in “present mode,” new changes will not show. It may be best to have an organizer “own” the team’s presentations to remove the team’s ability to edit by a particular deadline. 
Have the team name, presenter’s name, team members' names, and “presentation number” of the last team on the slide to stay visible to the audience while scoring. Perhaps it could be the team’s title slide with that additional information added. 
Make sure all teams send in a recorded pitch video before the session, just in case a team was unable to attend the demo day for any reason (medical, emergency..) or even for reasons such as having terrible internet connection and being unable to connect and join the demo day. Share the folder of “recorded pitch videos” with all the programs team and facilitators.

KEY POINTS: 
Online demo days can be as effective as in-person. There are different ways to facilitate the event online, and plenty of tools are available to help you make the most of it.

A key challenge area for accelerators measures impact. As yet, an agreed framework for measuring the performance of an accelerator program does not exist, but standard metrics collected and published so far include the following:

Stage 7: Program Epilogue: Post-Program Support
It is easy to see the duration of the program as a set timeframe for which the demo day marks the end. But this isn’t the way that accelerators perceive it. On graduating from an accelerator program, companies are still extremely young, and potentially not yet viable for investment. Everything an accelerator program does is geared toward giving its cohorts the best possible chance of survival after graduation. So it makes sense that most offer post-program support to maintain or enhance startups’ investment viability for as long as possible. 
It can typically include the following:
Public relations opportunities
Connections with investors
Board participation
HR/recruitment support
Local meet-ups
Online communities with funding and promotion opportunities
Office space
Alumni Network
All accelerators acknowledge their alumni network as a valuable asset of the program: maintaining an alumni database is, therefore, a priority. Some host online communities and alumni events to create and develop the alumni network. Others call on the help of alumni when selecting a new cohort of potential startups. There is also the phenomenon of recycling founders, where startups take in unsuccessful alumni as members of their team if they consider them valuable.
Follow-on Investment
Accelerated startups still struggle with gaps between seed funding and successfully raising Series A investment. To help combat this, some accelerators offer to follow–on investment once the program is finished; they can sometimes go some way towards bridging funding gaps. This could be by providing staged investments or an additional capital infusion after graduation.
Mentorship, Perks, and Opportunities
Once enterprises are part of an accelerator. They will be part of the community for life. They can expand their business and network with access to a talented group of founders, investors, mentors, and industry leaders. Additionally, the accelerator will typically have onboarded perks partners, providing the enterprises with discounts and access to helpful resources. Finally, keeping in touch with the accelerator community can be beneficial as program managers often share resources, opportunities, and other relevant information.

Appendix
Running Hybrid Programs
We can think of the acceleration programs in two models: 
Those that run face-to-face, which allow entrepreneurs to meet in a physical space at the same time, and 
Those that are carried out regardless of physical barriers, the time zone, the thousands of kilometers of distance between people, or even complex situations (such as those we have been experiencing in the last years).
Virtual accelerator programs are growing in popularity and have several advantages for founders and program teams. Virtual programs can also be delivered in a hybrid format, blending both online & offline elements. Virtual and Hybrid Accelerator programs allow
Improved Flexibility
One of the main benefits of hybrid programs is improved flexibility, which is becoming extremely important within the sector. Generally speaking, entrepreneurs want as many options as possible, and the ability to move from in-person to remote can be invaluable. Access to recorded sessions offers a second chance at missed sessions, memory refreshers, and a deeper reflection of session discussions.
Work with a more significant number of enterprises from much broader geographic areas.
The most exciting aspect of hybrid programs for many entrepreneurs is their potential to open up access to learning. On a basic level, when in-person is the only option available, all entrepreneurs need to be within traveling distance of the accelerator throughout the entire duration of their course. However, It is not necessarily the case with hybrid programs, which can mean more people can participate. This will expose the teams to meet people coming from diverse cultural backgrounds. In turn, this will lead to an increased cultural quotient and enhanced collective intelligence exercises. 
Support your Accelerator community, even during lockdowns
One problem we’ve run into in the past is the limited pool of mentors available for any given in-person workshop. Virtual programming has freed us up to engage world-class mentors from anywhere, including mentors that bring enormous technical, business, and market knowledge and speak the language of the startups in our cohort – culturally and literally.
Leveraging your workshop content to create a reusable library
E-Learning is no longer a simple byproduct of the information age and Internet access. It’s become an invaluable resource to educators, harnessing a new knowledge-sharing model wherein learners now possess the tools to learn at their own pace. Some online tools allow for quickly creating tests/quizzes, templates, and other resources. Practical benefits include tracking digital assignments’ submissions and reusing or reconstructing a course curriculum using new course templates.
KEY POINTS: 
Hybrid programs allow program managers to work with:
Improved Flexibility
A more significant number of enterprises from much broader geographic areas
Supporting your Accelerator community, even during lockdowns
Leveraging your workshop content to create a reusable library

Facilitation for Amazing Online and Offline Experiences
People learn through doing, practicing, and sharing. People also know best when they’re having fun! When they’re engaged and happy. 
Critical Aspects of Facilitation 
The same care for organizing an offline event should go into managing an online event, whether as small as a meeting with a few people or as big as a major conference or demo day. 
The medium is the message. A well-planned and well-facilitated event can have more engagement and impact than a poorly planned or facilitated event. 
Create Bridges Between the Physical and the Virtual
Play games and pass items back and forth between screens 
Share tea, coffee, or a meal while on a call 
Make a gift box of friendly perks/treats/tools to help them in the accelerator, and things to do fun games/activities with: 
Inspirational items (posters, notebooks, magnets, etc.)  
Shirts, hats, or something to wear 
Clown noses or fun items (in wrapping that disguises what they are until use) 
Tools for activities, such as printouts of frameworks, post-its, pens, activity cards, etc.
Stretching exercises, especially after having been at the laptop for more than half an hour.
Sharing music: In each session, let a participant choose the session’s background music
Whiteboard: share the whiteboard before the session begins and ask each participant to share a motivational quote/message.
Simple Tips for Increasing Engagement Online 
Eye contact: Look at the camera (not the screen) when talking, especially when recording something 
The background: Something nice? Art? Outdoors? Inspiring? A banner with logos? 
Sound: Use a better mic if possible, definitely headphones. Make sure nothing is rubbing against the microphone or mic cable while talking. 
Appearance: Try to be as “close to in-person” as possible … What are you wearing? Try not to wear big headphones. 
Stand up when talking (it changes body language and energy).
Mute yourself whenever you’re not speaking to avoid interrupting the speaker
Make sure your Zoom name is adjusted and has your team/organization/role in it as well

input.title: Bloom Assessment Framework: Integrated Growth Approach
input.content:
# Bloom Assessment Framework: Integrated Growth Approach

## Core Principles

1. **Integration Over Separation**
- Personal and professional growth are interconnected parts of the entrepreneurial journey
- Assessment should mirror this natural integration rather than artificially separate them
- Every business milestone has both personal and organizational implications

2. **Growth Over Measurement**
- Focus on capturing progression rather than before/after snapshots
- Embrace the journey of deepening understanding
- Recognize that increased awareness may initially appear as decreased confidence

3. **Action Over Analysis**
- Assessments should directly inform action steps
- Every insight should link to specific resources and opportunities
- Measurement should serve development, not just documentation

4. **Community Over Individual**
- Growth happens in context of peers, mentors, and ecosystem
- Assessment should capture both individual and collective progress
- Learning from others' journeys enriches personal development

## The New Approach

### 1. ECAT as the Central Framework
- ECAT becomes the primary lens through which we view development
- Personal and universal competencies are mapped to relevant ECAT elements
- Well-being indicators are integrated into organizational capacity measures

### 2. Progressive Depth Model
Instead of pre/post measurements, we track four levels of understanding:
1. **Awareness** - Recognition of the element's importance
2. **Understanding** - Grasp of how it applies to their context
3. **Integration** - Active application in business operations
4. **Mastery** - Ability to teach and guide others

### 3. Real-time Growth Capture
Weekly touchpoints include:
- Power moves documentation
- Learning moment reflection
- Peer feedback integration
- Mentor observations

### 4. Development Portfolio
Teams build evidence of growth through:
- Documented "aha moments"
- Applied learning examples
- Impact stories
- Community contributions

## Implementation Framework

### Phase 1: Initial Mapping (Week 1)
- Complete streamlined ECAT
- Identify priority development areas
- Set learning objectives
- Match with relevant resources

### Phase 2: Weekly Rhythm (Weeks 2-11)
- Monday: Power move planning
- Wednesday: Peer learning session
- Friday: Reflection and documentation
- Monthly: Deep dive review

### Phase 3: Growth Portfolio (Weeks 12-16)
- Curate evidence of development
- Document key transformations
- Capture community impact
- Plan ongoing growth

## Measurement Integration

### Personal Growth Indicators
- Well-being elements mapped to business outcomes
- Universal skills demonstrated through business actions
- Character strengths applied to leadership challenges

### Professional Growth Indicators
- Business milestone achievement
- Team capacity development
- Resource utilization effectiveness
- Market impact measures

### Community Growth Indicators
- Peer support contributions
- Knowledge sharing
- Ecosystem engagement
- Collective learning moments

## Expected Outcomes

1. **For Teams**
- Clearer development pathway
- More actionable insights
- Better integration of personal and professional growth
- Stronger community connection

2. **For Program Managers**
- Streamlined assessment process
- More meaningful progress tracking
- Better resource allocation
- Clearer impact demonstration

3. **For Stakeholders**
- More holistic view of impact
- Better understanding of value creation
- Clearer connection between personal and organizational growth
- Stronger evidence base for support

## Critical Questions for Implementation

1. **Standardization Challenge**
How can we ensure consistent interpretation of depth levels across different mentors and programs while maintaining the nuanced understanding needed for personal development?

2. **Evidence Reliability**
In moving away from traditional pre/post measurements, how do we rigorously demonstrate program impact to stakeholders who may be accustomed to more conventional metrics?

3. **Resource Requirements**
Does this more integrated, continuous assessment approach actually reduce administrative burden, or does it simply shift it to different points in the program?

4. **Scalability Concerns**
How well will this framework scale across different contexts, cultures, and program sizes? What elements might need to be modular or adaptable?

5. **Integration Complexity**
While the integrated approach makes theoretical sense, how do we ensure we're not losing valuable insights by combining previously separate measurements into one framework?

1. Which aspects of the integrated framework resonate most strongly with your experience?
2. Do you see any immediate challenges in implementing the progressive depth model?
3. Would this approach better address the Dunning-Kruger effect you've observed?

The framework aims to solve multiple challenges simultaneously while simplifying the overall process, but I'm curious whether you think it achieves the right balance between comprehensiveness and practicality.

messages.content:
Let me address these key questions and the ECAT/wellbeing integration challenge:

1. **Demonstrating Program Impact**
Instead of relying solely on pre/post measurements, we could demonstrate impact through:

a) **Growth Portfolio Evidence**:
- Documented examples of applying learning
- Before/after business metrics tied to specific ECAT elements
- Video testimonials capturing key transformation moments
- Case studies showing progression through depth levels

b) **Progressive Milestone Achievement**:
```
Level 1 (Awareness): "I understand what financial planning means"
Level 2 (Understanding): "I can create basic financial projections"
Level 3 (Integration): "I'm using financial data to make decisions"
Level 4 (Mastery): "I can teach others financial planning"
```

c) **Impact Triangulation**:
- Business metrics (revenue, customers, etc.)
- Growth documentation (portfolio evidence)
- External validation (mentor assessments, customer feedback)

2. **Reducing Resource Requirements**
We can actually reduce resources by:
- Using technology for automated tracking
- Integrating assessment into existing touchpoints
- Building assessment into natural program rhythms

For example:
```
Weekly mentor check-in → Capture growth moment
Monthly cohort meeting → Group reflection point
Demo day preparation → Portfolio compilation
```

3. **Standardization Solution**
Create a clear rubric for each depth level:

```
Awareness:
- Can explain the concept
- Recognizes its importance
- Identifies relevant examples

Understanding:
- Can apply to own context
- Makes connections to other elements
- Identifies improvement opportunities

Integration:
- Shows consistent application
- Measures results
- Adapts approach based on feedback

Mastery:
- Teaches others effectively
- Creates new approaches
- Demonstrates systemic understanding
```

4. **ECAT and Wellbeing Integration**
You raise an excellent point about the difference between business and personal measures. Here's a potential solution:

Create a dual-layer ECAT:
```
Viewing artifacts created via the Analysis Tool web feature preview isn’t yet supported on mobile.
```



For each ECAT element, we assess both:
1. **Business Capacity**: How well the organization performs
2. **Personal Capacity**: How the individual is developing

For example, under "Resource Access":
- **Business**: Does the organization effectively acquire and manage resources?
- **Personal**: Is the individual developing their ability to identify and secure resources?

This creates a more holistic view while maintaining distinct measures. We could structure it like:

```markdown
ECAT Element: Resource Access

Business Level:
- Systems for resource management
- Resource allocation efficiency
- Resource sustainability

Personal Level:
- Confidence in seeking resources
- Network building capacity
- Resource strategy skills

Integration Points:
- How personal growth enables better business outcomes
- How business progress supports personal development
```

This approach would:
- Maintain separate measures for personal and organizational growth
- Show how they influence each other
- Allow for individual tracking within team context
- Provide clearer development pathways

Would this dual-layer approach help address your concern about maintaining individual wellbeing measures while integrating them into the ECAT framework? We could potentially create specific personal development indicators that parallel each ECAT business measure.

input.content:
# Integrated Business-Personal ECAT Framework

## 🎯 Strategy: Customer Understanding & Value Creation

### Business Layer: Understanding Customer Needs
*Team fills as reflection*

**Ideation Stage**
- "We have conducted initial customer interviews and documented basic needs"
- "We've started mapping customer pain points"

**Prototype Stage**
- "We have validated customer needs through MVP testing"
- "We have documentation of customer feedback and iterations"

**Growth Stage**
- "We have established customer feedback loops"
- "We continuously evolve our understanding through systematic engagement"

### Personal Layer: Customer Empathy Development
*Mentor/Coach fills as assessment*

**Ideation Stage**
- How effectively does the founder listen to and internalize customer feedback?
- How comfortable is the founder with customer discovery conversations?

**Prototype Stage**
- How well does the founder translate customer insights into product decisions?
- How effectively does the founder balance different stakeholder needs?

**Growth Stage**
- How well does the founder anticipate and respond to evolving customer needs?
- How effectively does the founder build and maintain customer relationships?

## 💡 Leadership & Decision Making

### Business Layer: Organizational Decision-Making
*Team fills as reflection*

**Ideation Stage**
- "We have basic decision-making processes in place"
- "We document key decisions and rationale"

**Prototype Stage**
- "We have structured decision-making frameworks"
- "We regularly review and learn from past decisions"

**Growth Stage**
- "We have robust governance and decision-making systems"
- "We effectively balance short and long-term considerations"

### Personal Layer: Leadership Development
*Mentor/Coach fills as assessment*

**Ideation Stage**
- How effectively does the founder make decisions under uncertainty?
- How well does the founder communicate decisions to stakeholders?

**Prototype Stage**
- How well does the founder delegate and empower others?
- How effectively does the founder build and lead teams?

**Growth Stage**
- How well does the founder develop other leaders?
- How effectively does the founder manage organizational complexity?

## 🧘‍♀️ Well-being & Resilience

### Business Layer: Organizational Well-being
*Team fills as reflection*

**Ideation Stage**
- "We have basic work-life boundaries in place"
- "We discuss team stress and burnout openly"

**Prototype Stage**
- "We have established well-being practices"
- "We measure and track team satisfaction"

**Growth Stage**
- "We have comprehensive well-being programs"
- "We foster a culture of sustainable growth"

### Personal Layer: Individual Well-being
*Mentor/Coach fills as assessment*

**Ideation Stage**
- How effectively does the founder manage personal energy?
- How well does the founder maintain work-life boundaries?

**Prototype Stage**
- How effectively does the founder handle stress and setbacks?
- How well does the founder support team well-being?

**Growth Stage**
- How well does the founder model sustainable leadership?
- How effectively does the founder build organizational resilience?

## Implementation Notes

1. **Assessment Process**:
- Teams complete business layer reflections monthly
- Mentors/coaches complete personal layer assessments quarterly
- Both use progressive stage-based framework

2. **Integration Points**:
- Monthly mentor sessions discuss both layers
- Quarterly reviews align personal and business growth
- Development plans address both dimensions

3. **Measurement Approach**:
- Business layer: Documentation and evidence-based
- Personal layer: Observable behaviors and outcomes
- Combined: Progress through startup stages

4. **Growth Tracking**:
- Progress tracked within each stage
- Movement between stages documented
- Integration of personal and business growth noted

input.content:
# 1. Assessment Questions Structure

## Strategy & Leadership Category
*Example showing progression that captures both business and personal growth*

### Understanding Customer Needs & Team Capacity

**Ideation Stage**
"Our team has started conducting customer interviews, and we're developing our capacity to listen and learn"
- No structured interviews yet
- Basic interviews completed
- Regular interviews with reflection
- Systematic learning process

**Prototype Stage**
"We validate assumptions and build team capability through testing"
- Initial testing started
- Regular testing with data
- Systematic testing program
- Culture of experimentation

**Growth Stage**
"We have established feedback systems and learning routines"
- Basic feedback collection
- Regular learning sessions
- Systematic improvement
- Teaching others

## Team Wellbeing & Resources Category

### Resource Management & Team Energy

**Ideation Stage**
"We manage our resources and team energy effectively"
- Basic tracking only
- Regular monitoring
- Systematic management
- Proactive optimization

*Similar structure for other categories...*

# 2. Enhanced Program Dashboard Format

## Monthly Progress Tracker
| Priority Area | Business Milestone | Personal/Team Growth | Activities Completed | Next Steps |
|--------------|-------------------|---------------------|---------------------|------------|
| Strategy | Customer interviews completed: 10/15 | Team more confident in user research | - Interview training
- Customer mapping | - Share learnings
- Update persona |
| Resources | Grant application submitted | Better at telling our story | - Pitch practice
- Story workshop | - Refine pitch
- Follow up |

## Quarterly Review
| Category | Start of Quarter | End of Quarter | Key Learning | Growth Evidence |
|----------|-----------------|----------------|--------------|-----------------|
| Strategy | Ideation Stage | Prototype Stage | "We learned how to balance user feedback with vision" | - Interview logs
- Prototype iterations |
| Team | Basic processes | Regular routines | "Regular checkins improve alignment" | - Meeting notes
- Team feedback |

# 3. Priority Area Goal Templates

## Structure for Goal Setting
When teams select a priority area, prompt them to complete:

```markdown
1. What we'll improve:
"We will strengthen [business area] by developing our [specific capacity]"

2. How we'll grow:
"Our team will build [personal/team capacity] through [specific practice]"

3. Success looks like:
"We'll know we've succeeded when [business indicator] and [team indicator]"

Example:
Priority Area: Customer Discovery

1. What we'll improve:
"We will strengthen our customer understanding by developing our interview and analysis capability"

2. How we'll grow:
"Our team will build empathy and listening skills through structured interview practice and reflection"

3. Success looks like:
"We'll know we've succeeded when we have 20 validated customer insights and the team is confidently conducting independent interviews"
```

## Monthly Check-in Prompt
```markdown
1. Business Progress:
- Key milestone achieved:
- Current challenge:
- Next priority:

2. Team Growth:
- New capability:
- Learning moment:
- Support needed:

3. Resources Used:
- Activities completed:
- Tools helpful:
- Additional needs:
```

## Implementation Notes

1. **Assessment Timing**:
- Initial assessment: Beginning of program
- Progress reflection: Monthly
- Deep review: Quarterly

2. **Dashboard Updates**:
- Weekly: Quick progress notes
- Monthly: Detailed reflection
- Quarterly: Stage progression

3. **Priority Area Focus**:
- Select 1-2 areas at a time
- Review every month
- Adjust based on progress

4. **Evidence Collection**:
- Activity completion
- Resource utilization
- Team reflections
- Mentor feedback

input.title: Rethinking Our Assessment Approach
input.content:
# Rethinking Our Assessment Approach

## Current Challenges
1. Too many separate assessments (ECAT, PERMAH, EntreComp)
2. Pre/post measurement issues (Dunning-Kruger effect)
3. Integration of personal and organizational growth
4. Data utilization challenges

## Key Questions We're Exploring
1. How do we measure both personal and organizational growth without overwhelming teams?
2. How can we better capture progress without traditional pre/post testing?
3. How do we maintain assessment value while streamlining the process?

## Potential Paths Forward

### Path 1: Progressive Growth Model
- Move from point-in-time measurement to journey tracking
- Focus on capturing growth moments and evidence
- Link personal and organizational development naturally

### Path 2: Integrated Framework Evolution
- Build on ECAT as core framework
- Find ways to incorporate personal elements
- Streamline measurement points

### Path 3: Simplified Assessment + Rich Documentation
- Reduce formal assessment burden
- Enhance natural growth documentation
- Focus on quality over quantity of measurement

## Key Considerations
1. Program Goals
   - Impact demonstration
   - Team development
   - Research validity

2. Practical Constraints
   - Current software capabilities
   - Program structure
   - Resource limitations

## Next Steps
1. Identify priority path
2. Experiment with specific elements
3. Gather feedback
4. Iterate approach

## Discussion Questions for Today
1. Which path resonates most with our goals?
2. What are the critical elements we must preserve?
3. How do we balance rigor and simplicity?

input.content:
# Assessment Strategy: Current State and Evolution

## What's Working Well
1. **ECAT as Core Tool**
- Guides program planning
- Helps teams identify priorities
- Enables focused resource allocation

2. **Self-Serve System**
- Library of activities
- Priority area identification
- Resource connection

3. **Program Planning Integration**
- Shapes program worksheets
- Guides mentor relationships
- Aligns team and program goals

## Current Challenges & Opportunities

### Immediate Considerations
1. **Measurement Quality**
- Pre/post validity issues (Dunning-Kruger effect)
- Need for meaningful progress tracking
- Balance between data and insight

2. **Stakeholder Needs**
- Teams: Need clear development paths
- Mentors: Need useful insights to guide
- Funders: Need clear outcome metrics
- Partners: Value framework alignment (e.g., EU/EntreComp)

3. **System Integration**
- Multiple frameworks (ECAT, PERMAH, EntreComp)
- Software capabilities
- Resource connection

### Core Purpose of Assessments
1. **For Participants**
- Frame personal/professional growth connection
- Unlock action through insight
- Build strong "why" for development
- Enable self-directed growth

2. **For Program**
- Match mentors effectively
- Guide resource allocation
- Track meaningful progress
- Demonstrate impact

## Evolution Paths

### Short-term (Next Program)
1. Maintain core ECAT structure
2. Enhance reflection capture
3. Better integrate personal elements
4. Improve mentor utilization

### Medium-term
1. Refine measurement approach
2. Strengthen framework integration
3. Enhance self-serve capabilities
4. Develop better progress indicators

### Long-term Vision
1. Validated measurement tools
2. Seamless personal/professional integration
3. Enhanced impact demonstration
4. Stronger ecosystem alignment

## Discussion Points
1. How might we better capture growth without compromising validity?
2. What's the minimum effective assessment framework?
3. How do we balance standardization with personalization?
4. What quick wins could we implement for the next program?

input.title: Assessment Value Analysis
input.content:
# Assessment Value Analysis

## Assessment Types & Stakeholder Value Matrix

| Assessment Type | Completion Burden | Value to Teams | Value to Mentors | Value to Program Managers | Value to Funders | Value for Research | Best Timing | Key Benefits | Key Challenges |
|----------------|------------------|----------------|------------------|-------------------------|------------------|-------------------|--------------|--------------|----------------|
| ECAT Pre/Post | High | Medium-High | Medium | High | High | Medium | Pre + Post | - Shows business progress
- Guides resource allocation
- Validates program impact | - Dunning-Kruger effect
- Time consuming
- May not reflect true growth |
| ECAT Ongoing | Medium | High | High | High | Medium | Low | Throughout | - Real-time guidance
- Actionable insights
- Natural integration | - Less rigorous
- Harder to quantify
- More complex to track |
| PERMAH Pre/Post | Medium | Medium | Low | Medium | Low | High | Pre + Post | - Validated tool
- Clear metrics
- Research value | - Not directly tied to business
- Personal nature
- Privacy concerns |
| PERMAH Check-ins | Low | High | Medium | Medium | Low | Low | Monthly | - Regular pulse check
- Low burden
- Supports wellbeing | - Less systematic
- Hard to aggregate
- Subjective |
| EntreComp Pre/Post | High | Medium | Medium | Medium | High | Medium | Pre + Post | - EU alignment
- Skill tracking
- Partner value | - Complex framework
- Time intensive
- Abstract concepts |
| EntreComp Self-Rating | Low | High | Medium | Low | Low | Low | As needed | - Self-directed
- Flexible
- Development focused | - Less rigorous
- Hard to compare
- Subjective |

## Priority Analysis

### Highest Value for Pre/Post:
1. ECAT
- Strongest link to business outcomes
- Most valuable for funders
- Clear progression markers

### Best for Ongoing Tracking:
1. PERMAH check-ins
- Low burden
- High personal value
- Supports intervention

### Most Partner/Funder Relevant:
1. EntreComp (alignment)
2. ECAT (outcomes)

## Recommendation Matrix

| Stakeholder | Must Have | Nice to Have | Can Skip |
|-------------|-----------|--------------|-----------|
| Teams | - ECAT ongoing
- Brief wellbeing checks | - Skills self-assessment
- Detailed progress tracking | - Full pre/post batteries |
| Mentors | - Current ECAT status
- Team priorities | - Wellbeing insights
- Skill gaps | - Detailed assessments |
| Program Managers | - ECAT pre/post
- Basic progress metrics | - Regular wellbeing data
- Skill development | - Complex correlations |
| Funders | - Business outcomes
- Stage progression | - Competency growth
- Program impact | - Personal development |
| Research Partners | - Validated measures
- Consistent data | - Multiple timepoints
- Rich qualitative | - Real-time tracking |

## Implementation Considerations

### Critical Success Factors:
1. Burden vs. Benefit ratio
2. Clear actionability
3. Stakeholder alignment
4. Resource requirements
5. Data quality

### Risk Factors:
1. Assessment fatigue
2. Data reliability
3. Resource constraints
4. Stakeholder buy-in
5. Implementation complexity

input.content:
# Assessment Value Matrix
(Scale 1-5, where 5 is highest)

## ECAT Assessment

| Stakeholder | Pre Only | Post Only | Pre-Post | Dynamic | Key Value | Effort Required | Implementation Complexity |
|------------|----------|-----------|-----------|----------|------------|-----------------|-------------------------|
| Research | 2 | 2 | 4 | 3 | Validates methodology | 4 | 3 |
| Funders | 2 | 3 | 5 | 4 | Shows program impact | 3 | 4 |
| Teams | 4 | 3 | 2 | 5 | Guides development | 3 | 3 |
| Program Managers | 5 | 3 | 4 | 5 | Program planning | 4 | 4 |
| Mentors | 4 | 2 | 3 | 5 | Direction setting | 2 | 3 |

## PERMAH Assessment

| Stakeholder | Pre Only | Post Only | Pre-Post | Dynamic | Key Value | Effort Required | Implementation Complexity |
|------------|----------|-----------|-----------|----------|------------|-----------------|-------------------------|
| Research | 3 | 2 | 5 | 4 | Validates wellbeing impact | 5 | 4 |
| Funders | 2 | 2 | 4 | 3 | Shows holistic impact | 3 | 4 |
| Teams | 4 | 3 | 2 | 5 | Personal insight | 4 | 3 |
| Program Managers | 3 | 2 | 4 | 4 | Support planning | 3 | 4 |
| Mentors | 4 | 2 | 3 | 5 | Understanding needs | 3 | 3 |

## EntreComp Assessment

| Stakeholder | Pre Only | Post Only | Pre-Post | Dynamic | Key Value | Effort Required | Implementation Complexity |
|------------|----------|-----------|-----------|----------|------------|-----------------|-------------------------|
| Research | 2 | 2 | 4 | 3 | Framework alignment | 4 | 4 |
| Funders | 4 | 3 | 5 | 4 | EU alignment | 3 | 3 |
| Teams | 3 | 3 | 2 | 4 | Skill mapping | 4 | 3 |
| Program Managers | 4 | 2 | 3 | 4 | Curriculum planning | 3 | 4 |
| Mentors | 3 | 2 | 3 | 4 | Skill development | 3 | 3 |

## Key Insights

1. **Highest Impact-to-Effort Ratio**:
- ECAT: Dynamic tracking for teams and program managers
- PERMAH: Pre-only for personal insight
- EntreComp: Pre-only for EU alignment

2. **Research Value**:
- PERMAH pre-post most valuable for research
- ECAT pre-post good for methodology validation
- EntreComp valuable for framework alignment

3. **Stakeholder Benefits**:
- Teams benefit most from dynamic/ongoing assessment
- Funders value pre-post for impact demonstration
- Program managers need initial assessment most

4. **Implementation Considerations**:
- Dynamic tracking highest complexity but best value
- Pre-only assessments good balance of effort/impact
- Post-only generally lowest value across board

## Recommendations

1. **Priority Measurements**:
- ECAT: Dynamic or at least pre-assessment
- PERMAH: Consider pre-only with ongoing reflection
- EntreComp: Pre-assessment with EU alignment focus

2. **Stakeholder-Specific Approaches**:
- Research: Focus on PERMAH pre-post
- Funders: ECAT pre-post
- Teams: Dynamic tracking where possible
- Program Managers: Strong initial assessments
- Mentors: Access to dynamic updates

Concept Note for the Leadership For Entrepreneurs Assessment
VIDEO WALKTHROUGH OF THIS DOCUMENT AND RESEARCH: 
https://www.loom.com/share/239383b6ed404ef1ba6cfd524ac6f762
Summary of video here:

FEEDBACK & QUESTIONS: 
Lots of great stuff … I love the stages, badges, observation of practices/behaviors, etc. 
Seems you folks have set it up to have two “pre-assessments” … Could those be combined into one pre-assessment? 
How about using the EntreComp levels rather than vague “1-5” or Likert scores? 
… plus the verifiable elements, experience, 3rd party validation, etc. I’d be curious if there are maybe 3 levels of this: 
Self-assessment (with improved levels) 
Self-assessment with evidence (text examples, etc.) 
3rd-party validated 
DigiComp, LifeComp, GreenComp, etc 
LifeComp looks awesome 


Introduction and Background
Bloom’s framework for Universal Skills, or 21st Century Skills, Soft Skills, Transversal Skills, and Skills to learn in Kindergarten, was derived from Skills Builder, a framework developed for younger learners. To align more with the goal of our programs to develop entrepreneurial skills and mindsets and to target a more appropriate age group, we are shifting towards other assessments, particularly looking at EntreComp from the EU. While Skills Builder and EntreComp (EC) suffer from a lack of universality, the EU's resources behind EC make it compelling. 
The EU has initiated a project called ECI, EntreComp Implementation, specifically designed to address the implementation gap. We use their implementation suggestion to focus on a subset of the EntreComp.

“Recognition precedes knowledge.” 
- Axel Honneth

This guiding quote inspires the decision to develop a public learning pathway, what Bloom used to call the leaderboard, to help people recognize the learnings and select their growth paths. To do this “out loud,” we are starting to explore public badging systems that allow people to see pathways, take assessments, and earn credentials they can keep with them forever after the program. (with no development on our part). 
See: 
EntreComp-Badges-Recognising-Entrepreneurial-Practice.pdf
for more information. We will explore cheap/free platforms this week to use during ACSI3.

Assessment Design and Considerations
We are proposing assessments to help learning happen. To recognize and incentivize - rather than “detect” - as some assessments attempt to do. As Bloom, we aim to promote entrepreneurial mindsets while training entrepreneurial skills. Developing a buffet-style assessment and intervention approach helps encourage engaged self-authored minds versus a more traditional scoring approach: “You are a C, here’s how you become a B, do XYZ.”
Thus, we propose three badging levels associated with three assessment styles.
(Explorer) Awareness: Taking the assessment without any reflection to understand where they stand (Everyone who does the mentimeter/other collaborative survey tool).
Reflection: Taking the assessment and sharing a reflection.
Validation: Taking the assessment and sharing a link to their actual work.

They can be three separate assessments or three assessments where two questions (reflection and validation) are optional.

Awareness:
We want people to be aware of the full extent of the competency while not overwhelming them with complexity. This short test should be fast/fun and support realizing what skills it takes to be an entrepreneur. 
The criteria we chose for the assessment questions are:
Relevance to Competency: Questions must directly relate to the core aspects of the competency they aim to assess.
Practical/Fact-based: Questions that expose the underlying competency yet are written and easily answerable by yes/no questions.
Depth of Insight: The ability of questions to elicit responses demonstrating a deep understanding and application of the competency.
Progression and Complexity: A mix of questions ranging from basic understanding to advanced application and strategic thinking.
Clarity and Conciseness: Questions should be clear, direct, and easily understood to avoid ambiguity and ensure accurate responses.
We chose two question types: T/F and Likert-scale. We do not believe this is the ideal question type, yet it’s a good start and will be fun. 
The scale-based questions have challenges; for example, some people will never put a 5, and some put 3s down without much thought. 
The T/F based on more concrete(potentially observable) elements can help resolve this. The challenge now becomes, what if people put T all the way across? 
One suggestion is to tell people at the start: “No one ever gets 100% taking this assessment; that would mean nothing to learn. Be honest, and let’s use this to find our learning adventure together.”
Taking this assessment unlocks the “EntreComp Explorer” badge. 
Reflection: 
This assessment follows the same structure as the first, except rather than T/F, participants are encouraged to write reflections on the EntreComp competencies they are learning about in the program. The reflection process is where the learning from the program is deepened and owned by the learner. Participants are encouraged to identify Entrepreneurial Skills within themselves and each other. Everyone is encouraged and welcomed to badge others when they recognize someone displaying a skill. 
Learners who take the reflection are valorized by a PM(or AI engine), indicating depth of thinking, identifying growth areas, selecting growth activities, and reflecting on growth activities completed.

In this phase, PMs and learners can badge each other. 

Validation:

Validation happens throughout the rest of the time in the program. As learners perform activities and participants create valuable content, PMs can validate their competencies with actual “portfolio pieces” that can be baked into their learning badge. 
This means that their badge will contain evidence of the Entrepreneurial competency it indicates.

The design of the assessment is likely to be two assessments. First, a T/F exploratory assessment mapping the territory. This is followed by an assessment of optional reflection questions and places to provide evidence (Google Docs, loom videos, testimonial blocks of text from customers, etc). The evidence we can accept for each competence already has a first draft proposal in the “Assessment Task/Activity” column of the “EntreComp Observable Activities” sheet on this spreadsheet: Individual Pillar Assessments and Questions.

A request: I would like this second assessment to have a new question type, one that has a ranking (move a slider from 0-5), and once the slider lands, a text field is unlocked with the number and a short text. You chose 4. Why do you think you’re a 4 in creativity? Reflect on this competency …. And then we include some reflection prompting.

Reasoning
Some of the thinking behind this structure is to:
Keep entrepreneurs in the driver's seat
Solve the issue of “slippage” - where funders see people scoring lower after a program due to their awareness about the skill increasing.
Increase engagement and involvement with participants by
Helping them see a map of the territory
Encouraging them to recognize skills within themselves and each other
Giving them the “power” to give informal badges, increasing the fun/gamification elements of our programs
To create verifiable skill badges, we can share them with our funders rather than the arbitrariness of 100 teams, which went from 4.2 to 4.3 in our assessment of a self-reported skill. 
Funders see 100 people got this badge, which you can see on bloom.pm/allbadges: 
this badge means XYZ; 
These are the names of the people that got this badge; 
Here is the evidence they provided that was validated by their PM (for formal badges). 
We can even have a bloom.pm/communityBadges where people can see the informal badges.
To make the first assessment useful, fast, and fun to do. Creating a framing for the rest of the program.

Self Critique and Suggestions
While this reasoning makes sense. I, Bilal, am still not 100% convinced that we should use EntreComp for our skills framework. 
There are cool reasons to do so; for instance, there was a mapping from these skills to roles within the ESCO (ESCO is the multilingual classification of European Skills, Competences, Qualifications and Occupations) Framework. You can find that in this PDF: ESCO-vs-EntreComp-Annex.pdf
For example, EntreComp framework and jobs that are related to them.  

While EntreComp has been out since 2016 (I think), it’s not gaining traction. It’s getting some research, but not a lot. Most of what’s happening is because the EU throws $ at it. It’s not taking off, and there’s not a lot of energy behind it. Most projects I saw developing things on/for it are dead, and their URLs are not renewed. 

The EU is doubling down on these “Comps,” though. I have two new ones that I would like to explore after proposing this framework and assessment approach. One is the GreenComp, and the other is LifeComp. 
LifeComp seems to be the most likely candidate for what we initially set out to do: replace the SkillsBuilder Universal Skills framework. We decided to focus on the entrepreneurial element - yet that may overlap with our EntCap assessment, especially as this assessment goes into the more practical elements. 

I’d love your feedback on these critiques and thoughts on making our assessments faster, more social, useful, more verifiable, less arbitrary, less self-reported, and most importantly, fun! 

One last bonus element to using EntreComp: this PDF has a nice guide and activities to develop each skill. So we quickly have some nice things for our library: 
Example for researching potential business opportunities:

EntreComp-Europe-Pocket-Book-for-Aspiring-Entrepreneurs.pdf
From the forward to the LifeComp PDF linked above.

For “pre-entrepreneurs,” - I believe working with things like LifeComp is important. Before you can build entrepreneurial skills, the LifeComp skills are, as the EU forward says, the baseline. They are:
Without some of these fundamentals, for instance, learning how to manage learning, flexibility (coachability is one of our criteria for selection), critical thinking to help with reflection and choosing a learning path, growth-mindset to make sure it all works. We may be unable to support participants in our entrepreneurial programs. 

How we want to go about this is interesting. A proposal that’s coming up for me is that for LifeComp, we may need a psychometric assessment/3rd party assessment or onboarding interviews that get analyzed. This will allow us to split people in our programs into two: one that goes into the LifeComp path to learn how to learn. And the others who hit a baseline level of competence here can join us in the EntreComp path.

Thank you for listening to my TED talk. 
+Bilal
Afterward.
You can find the Leadership for Entrepreneurship assessments below. Both assessments are also into: 
Individual Pillar Assessments and Questions
>> Awareness / ACSI3 version: Leadership Assessment - Awareness
>> Reflection version (filtered to ECI categories): Leadership Assessment - Reflection]]]

input.title: Assessment Framework: Key Insights and Strategy
input.content:
# Assessment Framework: Key Insights and Strategy

## Core Themes Emerging

1. **Progressive Recognition vs Traditional Measurement**
- Move from "detecting" to "recognizing and incentivizing"
- Three-tier approach: Awareness → Reflection → Validation
- Focus on growth journey rather than static scores

2. **Evidence-Based Progression**
- Self-assessment (basic awareness)
- Self-assessment with reflection (deeper understanding)
- Validated evidence (practical demonstration)

3. **Stakeholder Value Alignment**
- Teams: Growth pathway visibility
- Funders: Verifiable progress evidence
- Program: Framework for support
- Research: Methodological validation

## Strategic Questions to Address

1. **Framework Integration**
- How can we maintain alignment with EU frameworks while simplifying assessment?
- Should LifeComp be a prerequisite/baseline before EntreComp?
- Can we create clear progression paths between frameworks?

2. **Assessment Design**
- How to make initial assessment both lightweight and meaningful?
- What's the right balance between reflection and evidence?
- How to integrate badging with assessment naturally?

3. **Measurement Approach**
- How to handle the Dunning-Kruger effect constructively?
- What evidence types best demonstrate progress?
- How to make validation manageable at scale?

## Recommended Strategy

1. **Initial Assessment**
- Quick, engaging awareness check
- Clear framework introduction
- Sets growth expectations

2. **Ongoing Documentation**
- Regular reflection prompts
- Evidence collection opportunities
- Peer recognition elements

3. **Progress Validation**
- Milestone-based evidence review
- Multi-stakeholder verification
- Portfolio building approach

## Key Considerations

1. **For Teams**
- Keep self-direction central
- Make progress visible
- Create value beyond measurement

2. **For Program**
- Balance rigor with engagement
- Enable scalable validation
- Support mentor engagement

3. **For Stakeholders**
- Provide clear progress evidence
- Enable framework alignment
- Demonstrate impact effectively

## Questions for Discussion

1. Could we create a "growth journey map" that integrates all frameworks while keeping assessment simple?

2. How might we use the badging system to solve both the Dunning-Kruger effect and the pre/post measurement challenge?

3. What's the minimum viable evidence needed at each stage to make progress meaningful to all stakeholders?

4. How can we maintain framework alignment (EU, EntreComp) while prioritizing user experience and engagement?

5. Should we consider LifeComp as a "roots" assessment and EntreComp as a "growth" assessment in our tree metaphor?

input.title: Growth Journey: Solutions and Framework Alignment
input.content:
# Growth Journey: Integrated Solutions

## 1. Growth Journey Map Integration

**Solution**: Create a three-layer growth map that mirrors tree growth:

**Roots** (LifeComp - Foundational Skills)
- Learning to learn
- Resilience development
- Critical thinking
- Basic self-awareness

**Trunk** (EntreComp - Core Growth)
- Business fundamentals
- Leadership development
- Resource management
- Implementation skills

**Branches/Fruit** (Outcomes)
- Business metrics
- Impact measures
- Team development
- Personal flourishing

## 2. Badge System for Growth Tracking

**Solution**: Use badges to mark growth stages rather than absolute measures:

**Root Badges** (Foundation)
- "Soil Explorer" - Basic awareness
- "Root Builder" - Applied learning skills
- "Growth Ready" - Demonstrated readiness

**Trunk Badges** (Development)
- "Sprout" - Initial implementation
- "Grower" - Consistent application
- "Cultivator" - Teaching others

**Fruit Badges** (Achievement)
- "First Harvest" - Initial outcomes
- "Abundant Growth" - Sustained results
- "Seed Spreader" - Ecosystem impact

This addresses Dunning-Kruger by:
- Celebrating increased awareness as progress
- Focusing on evidence rather than self-perception
- Creating positive framing for deeper understanding

## 3. Minimum Viable Evidence

**For Roots** (LifeComp):
- Learning reflection logs
- Peer feedback documentation
- Applied learning examples

**For Trunk** (EntreComp):
- Implementation documentation
- Resource utilization examples
- Team development evidence

**For Fruit** (Outcomes):
- Business metrics
- Impact documentation
- Stakeholder testimonials

## 4. Framework Alignment While Prioritizing Experience

**Solution**: Layer frameworks naturally:

1. **Entry Point**:
- Simple awareness assessment
- Growth journey visualization
- Clear next steps

2. **Development Path**:
- Framework elements introduced progressively
- Evidence collected through natural work
- Alignment shown through outcomes

3. **Documentation**:
- Auto-collected evidence where possible
- Integration with existing workflows
- Natural connection to EU frameworks

## 5. LifeComp as Roots Assessment

**Yes, because**:
1. Provides foundation for growth
2. Identifies readiness for advanced work
3. Shows clear development pathway

**Implementation**:
- Initial quick assessment
- Ongoing development support
- Clear progression markers

## Practical Implementation

1. **Program Start**:
- Quick LifeComp check
- Growth journey mapping
- Initial badge earning

2. **During Program**:
- Weekly growth documentation
- Monthly reflection points
- Badge progression

3. **Program End**:
- Portfolio compilation
- Impact documentation
- Future growth planning

## Benefits for Stakeholders

**Teams**:
- Clear growth pathway
- Meaningful recognition
- Portable credentials

**Program Managers**:
- Simplified tracking
- Clear progress markers
- Framework alignment

**Funders**:
- Verifiable progress
- Clear impact measures
- Framework alignment

## Key Success Metrics

1. **Engagement**:
- Badge completion rates
- Evidence quality
- Peer recognition

2. **Growth**:
- Stage progression
- Capability development
- Outcome achievement

3. **Impact**:
- Business results
- Personal development
- Ecosystem contribution
